comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2909004787/ and www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2850356157/ are at the same event. Mrs Macy is Anne Sullivan Macy

comment.author: 69005233@N00
comment._content: I wonder if this might be the International Flower Show in New York City.  The inaugural show was held in April 1913 and Helen Keller was reported to have visited there, as she was doing a speaking tour (her first in NY) at the time.  (source, NY Times March 31, 1913, Monday ... "Helen Keller...appeared on the lecture platform for the first time in New York last night at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre.")

comment.author: 69005233@N00
comment._content:
Further digging, and yes, this was in April 1913, per this story/photo in The Indianapolis Star, 14 April 1913, page 10, col 2

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/curiouskiwi/3224152903/]

Famous Blind Girl Honored at Flower Show.
Mrs John Macy, Miss Helen Keller
-Copyright, International.

"Miss Helen Keller, the famous deaf, dumb and blind woman, was one of the 
prominent visitors at the international flower show held in New York.  She was
presented with the prize American Beauty roses.  She is shown with Mrs. John
 Macy of the presentation committee."

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Swang - 

Is "Mrs. John Macy of the presentation committee" the same Mrs. John A. Macy who was previously known as Anne Sullivan?

comment.author: 69005233@N00
comment._content: I'm sure it is... and I'm not 100% convinced that the Indianapolis Star was correct in their caption of "Mrs John Macy of the presentation committee".  It is indeed Mrs John (Ann Sullivan) Macy, but was she really on the presentation committee?

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Brenda Anderson - I agree, it looks like the same woman in the photogrpahs I've checked for comparison and I agree that the item in the Indianapolis Star  may be miscaptioned because I can't find any reference to Mrs. John (Anne Sullivan) Macy being involved in a flower show or committee.  

So far that is.
